Mengungkap jual beli pembantu rumah tangga melalui 'pasar budak online' yang sedang tren di Kuwait
01 Nov 2019, 08:50 by BBC


Lewat aplikasi daring, ribuan perempuan dijual sebagai pekerja rumah tangga di pasar budak ilegal di Timur Tengah.

Jika Anda berkeliling di jalan-jalan Kuwait, ada berbagai perempuan yang tak kelihatan. Mereka berada di balik pintu tertutup, hak asasi mereka dilanggar, dan bisa dijual ke penawar tertinggi.
Tapi cobalah ambil telepon seluler dan Anda bisa lihat ribuan foto mereka, dikelompokkan berdasarkan negara asal. Mereka dijual dengan harga beberapa ribu dollar AS.
Penyelidikan rahasia yang dilakukan oleh BBC News Arab menemukan pekerja rumah tangga dibawa secara ilegal dan dijual melalui internet di pasar gelap yang sedang tren.
Ini dimungkinkan melalui aplikasi di Google Play dan Apple App Store, serta tagar yang dipacu oleh algoritma di Instagram, platform milik Facebook.
Pasar budak
"Apa yang mereka lakukan adalah promosi terhadap pasar budak online," kata Urmila Bhoola, Pelapor Khusus PBB soal perbudakan modern.
"Jika Google, Apple, Facebook, atau perusahaan lain menyediakan aplikasi semacam itu, mereka harus ikut bertanggung jawab," imbuhnya.


Kisah Sara yang berhasil lolos dari perbudakan modern di Inggris


Mengapa di Inggris masih ada perbudakan modern, dan kali ini jumlah korbannya mencapai 'rekor'?


Delapan putri Uni Emirat Arab bersalah menyiksa PRT


Sebanyak sembilan dari 10 rumah tangga di Kuwait memiliki pembantu rumah tangga. Mereka berasal dari berbagai negara miskin di dunia yang datang ke Kawasan Teluk, dengan tujuan mencari uang untuk keluarga di kampung halaman masing-masing.
Dengan menyamar sebagai pasangan yang baru tiba di Kuwait, tim BBC Arab berbicara kepada 57 orang pengguna aplikasi ini dan mengunjungi puluhan lainnya yang ditawari pekerja rumah tangga melalui aplikasi jual beli komoditas bernama '4Sale'.
Hampir semua penjual menyarankan agar paspor pekerja rumah tangga ini disita dan kesempatan untuk mengakses telepon sangat dibatasi atau ditiadakan sama sekali.
Aplikasi 4Sale ini juga memungkinkan kita untuk menyaring para calon pekerja rumah tangga itu berdasar ras. Kelompok harga pun berbeda berdasar berbagai kategori.
Tim kami yang menyamar kerap mendengar komentar semisal, "Yang terjorok dari India," untuk menggambarkan perempuan-perempuan itu.


Pelapor Khusus untuk PBB Urmila Bhoola menyebut ini sebagai pasar budak daring.

Pelanggaran hak asasi manusia
Tim kami disarankan oleh pengguna aplikasi - yang menyatakan diri sebagai 'pemilik' para perempuan PRT ini - untuk melanggar hak asasi mereka, misalnya dengan tak memberi waktu libur "barang sehari, semenit atau sedetik".
Seorang pria, anggota kepolisian, ingin segera menjual pekerja rumah tangganya. Katanya, "percayalah, dia sangat baik, sering ketawa dan wajahnya penuh senyum. Bahkan kalau kamu suruh dia kerja sampai pukul lima pagi, dia tak akan mengeluh".
Katanya kepada tim BBC, pekerja rumah tangga ini diperlakukan sebagai komoditas. "Ada yang membeli PRT seharga 600 KD (dinar kuwait) (sekitar Rp27,7 juta), dan menjualnya lagi seharga 1.000 KD (Rp46 juta)."


Tim BBC News Arabic merekam percakapan dengan para penjual pekerja rumah tangga di Kuwait.

Ia memberi panduan bagi pembeli: "Jangan serahkan paspornya kepadanya. Anda adalah sponsornya. Buat apa Anda kasih paspornya kepadanya?"
Satu kasus yang mengejutkan, tim BBC ditawari seorang remaja berusia 16 tahun bernama 'Fatou'.


Polisi Austria bongkar jaringan perdagangan perempuan Cina


Bagaimana seharusnya kita memperlakukan pekerja rumah tangga?


TKW di Hong Kong: Kehamilan jadi alasan untuk menetap di Hong Kong


Ia diselundupkan dari Guinea, Afrika Barat, dan bekerja sebagai pembantu rumah tangga di Kuwait selama enam bulan, sekalipun hukum Kuwait menyatakan pekerjaan itu hanya boleh dilakukan pekerja berusia 21 tahun ke atas.
Promosi Fatou oleh penjualnya mencantumkan keterangan promosi bahwa si penjual ini tidak pernah memberi waktu libur buat Fatou, menahan paspor dan telepon genggamnya serta tak pernah membiarkannya keluar rumah sendirian. Semua hal itu legal di Kuwait.
Izin sponsor
"Ini adalah intisari dari perbudakan modern," kata Urmila Bhoola. "Kita lihat bagaimana seorang anak dijual dan diperdagangkan seperti budak, seperti sepotong barang."
Di banyak tempat di Kawasan Teluk, pekerja rumah tangga dibawa ke negara itu oleh agen, kemudian didaftarkan secara resmi ke pemerintah.
Calon majikan membayar biaya kepada agen, dan menjadi sponsor resmi pekerja rumah tangga itu.
Di bawah sistem yang dikenal dengan nama "Kafala" itu, pekerja rumah tangga tak bisa berhenti atau beralih pekerjaan, juga tak boleh meninggalkan Kuwait tanpa izin dari sponsornya.


Fatou (bukan nama sebenarnya), 16 tahun, asal Guinea kami rekam saat bersama dengan penjualnya di Kuwait City.

Aturan hukum tahun 2015 di Kuwait membuat negeri itu menjadi salah satu yang paling tegas melindungi pekerja rumah tangga. Namun aturan itu tak populer.
Aplikasi seperti 4Sale memungkinkan majikan menjual hak 'kafala' mereka ke majikan lain dan mengambil untung dari situ. Ini memangkas peran agen dan menciptakan pasar gelap yang membuat posisi para perempuan ini menjadi rentan terhadap penyiksaan dan eksploitasi.
Pasar budak daring ini tak hanya terjadi di Kuwait.
Di Arab Saudi penyelidikan kami menemukan ratusan perempuan dijual di Haraj, sebuah aplikasi populer lainnya untuk komoditi. Ada lagi ratusan penjualan di Instagram, platform yang dimiliki oleh Facebook.
"Neraka sesungguhnya"
Tim BBC pergi ke Guinea untuk mencoba menghubungi keluarga Fatou, remaja yang dijual di Kuwait tadi.
Setiap tahun, ratusan perempuan dijual dari sini ke Kawasan Teluk untuk menjadi pekerja rumah tangga.
"Kuwait itu neraka yang sesungguhnya," kata salah satu bekas pembantu rumah tanggal. Ia ingat bahwa ia pernah disuruh tidur oleh majikannya di tempat yang sama dengan sapi.
"Rumah-rumah di Kuwait sangat buruk," kata yang lain. "Tak bisa tidur, tak ada makanan, tak ada apa-apa."


Tim BBC mengikuti Fatou kembali ke kampung halamannya di Conakry, ibu kota Guinea.

Fatou ditemukan oleh pihak berwenang Kuwait dan dibawa ke penampungan pekerja rumah tangga yang dikelola pemerintah. Dua hari kemudian ia dikembalikan ke Guinea karena masih anak-anak.
Fatou berkata kepada BBC: "Mereka sering berteriak kepada saya, dan memanggil saya dengan nama binatang. Sakit dan sedih rasanya. Tapi saya tak bisa berbuat apa-apa."
Kini ia kembali bersekolah di Conakry. Ia meminta tim BBC untuk mengunjunginya, "Saya senang sekali. Bahkan sekarang saya membicarakannya, Hidup saya lebih baik sekarang. Rasanya seperti keluar dari perbudakan."
Tagar yang dilarang
Pemerintah Kuwaiti megatakan mereka "sedang berperang melawan perilaku semacam ini" dan berkeras bahwa aplikasi semacam itu akan "diteliti dengan sangat saksama".
Hingga kini tak ada tindakan hukum atau tindakan signifikan lainnya terhadap perempuan yang mencoba menjual Fatou kepada kami. Si penjual juga tidak menanggapi permintaan BBC untuk berkomentar.
Sejak tim BBC menghubungi perusahaan 4Sale terkait temuan kami, mereka menghilangkan bagian pekerja rumah tangga dari pasar komoditas mereka. Facebook juga melarang penggunaan tagar "خادمات للتنازل#" "#maidsfortransfer" yang selama ini dijadikan alat.
Tidak ada komentar dari aplikasi jual beli komoditas asal Arab Saudi, Haraj.
Baik Google dan Apple mengatakan kepada BBC bahwa tipe perilaku semacam ini tidak ada tempat di pasar aplikasi mereka.
Dan mereka bekerja bersama pengembang aplikasi untuk memperbaiki pencegahan kegiatan ilegal di platform mereka.
text:
Uncovering the sale and purchase of domestic servants through the 'online slave market' that is trending in Kuwait
01 Nov 2019, 08:50 by BBC


Through online applications, thousands of women are sold as domestic workers in the illegal slave market in the Middle East.

If you walk around the streets of Kuwait, there are various invisible women. They are behind closed doors, their human rights are violated, and can be sold to the highest bidder.
But try taking a cell phone and you can see thousands of their photos, grouped by country of origin. They are sold for several thousand US dollars.
A secret investigation carried out by BBC News Arab found domestic workers illegally brought in and sold through the internet on the trending black market.
This is possible through applications on Google Play and Apple App Store, as well as hashtags that are driven by algorithms on Instagram, Facebook's platform.
Slave Market
"What they are doing is promoting an online slave market," said Urmila Bhoola, the UN Special Rapporteur on modern slavery.
"If Google, Apple, Facebook or other companies provide such applications, they must take responsibility," he added.


The story of Sara who survived modern slavery in England


Why in Britain is there still modern slavery, and this time the number of victims reached a 'record'?


Eight United Arab Emirates daughters are guilty of torturing domestic workers


Nine out of 10 households in Kuwait have domestic helpers. They come from various poor countries in the world who come to the Gulf Region, with the aim of earning money for families in their hometowns.
Disguised as a newly arrived couple in Kuwait, the BBC Arab team spoke to 57 users of the application and visited dozens of others who were offered domestic workers through a commodity trading app called '4Sale'.
Nearly all sellers suggested that the domestic worker's passport be confiscated and the opportunity to access the telephone was severely restricted or completely eliminated.
This 4Sale application also allows us to screen prospective domestic workers based on race. Price groups also differ based on various categories.
Our undercover team often hears comments such as, "The sagged ones from India," to describe the women.


The Special Rapporteur for the United Nations Urmila Bhoola called this the online slave market.

Human rights violations
Our team is advised by application users - who claim to be the 'owners' of these domestic workers - to violate their human rights, for example by not giving time off for "a day, a minute or a second".
A man, a member of the police, wants to immediately sell his domestic workers. He said, "believe me, he was very kind, often laughing and his face was full of smiles. Even if you told him to work until five in the morning, he would not complain".
He told the BBC team that these domestic workers were treated as commodities. "There are those who buy domestic workers for 600 KD (Dinar Kuwait) (around Rp. 27.7 million), and sell them again for 1,000 KD (Rp. 46 million)."


The BBC News Arabic team recorded conversations with sellers of domestic workers in Kuwait.

He gave a guide for the buyer: "Don't hand over the passport to him. You are the sponsor. Why do you give him the passport?"
One surprising case, the BBC team was offered a 16 year old teenager named 'Fatou'.


Austrian police dismantle Chinese women's trafficking network


How should we treat domestic workers?


TKW in Hong Kong: Pregnancy is a reason to stay in Hong Kong


She was smuggled from Guinea, West Africa, and worked as a domestic servant in Kuwait for six months, even though Kuwaiti law states that work can only be done by workers aged 21 years and over.
Fatou's promotion by the seller included promotional information that the seller had never given Fatou time off, held his passport and cellphone and never let him leave the house alone. All of that is legal in Kuwait.
Sponsor permission
"This is the essence of modern slavery," Urmila Bhoola said. "We see how a child is sold and traded like a slave, like a piece of goods."
In many parts of the Gulf Region, domestic workers are brought to the country by agents, then officially registered with the government.
The prospective employer pays the agency fees, and becomes the official sponsor of the domestic worker.
Under the system known as "Kafala", domestic workers cannot stop or change jobs, nor can they leave Kuwait without permission from their sponsors.


Fatou (not his real name), 16 years old, from Guinea we recorded when together with the seller in Kuwait City.

The 2015 law in Kuwait makes the country one of the most assertive in protecting domestic workers. But the rules are not popular.
Applications like 4Sale allow employers to sell their 'kafala' rights to other employers and profit from it. This cuts the role of agents and creates a black market that makes these women vulnerable to torture and exploitation.
The online slave market is not only happening in Kuwait.
In Saudi Arabia our investigation found hundreds of women for sale in Haraj, another popular application for commodities. There are hundreds more sales on Instagram, a platform owned by Facebook.
"Real hell"
The BBC team went to Guinea to try to contact the Fatou family, teenagers who were sold in Kuwait earlier.
Every year, hundreds of women are sold from here to the Gulf Region to become domestic workers.
"Kuwait is the real hell," said one former housemaid, dated. He remembered that he had been told to sleep by his employer in the same place as a cow.
"Houses in Kuwait are very bad," said another. "Can't sleep, no food, nothing."


The BBC team followed Fatou back to his hometown in Conakry, the capital of Guinea.

Fatou was found by Kuwaiti authorities and taken to a government-run domestic worker shelter. Two days later he was returned to Guinea because he was still a child.
Fatou said to the BBC: "They often shouted at me, and called me by the name of an animal. It was painful and sad. But I could not do anything."
Now he is back at school in Conakry. He asked the BBC team to visit him, "I am very happy. Even now I am talking about it, my life is better now. It feels like getting out of slavery."
Banned hashtags
The Kuwaiti government said they were "at war with this kind of behavior" and insisted that such applications would be "examined very closely".
Until now there has been no legal action or other significant action against women who are trying to sell Fatou to us. The seller also did not respond to BBC requests to comment.
Since the BBC team contacted the 4Sale company regarding our findings, they have eliminated the share of domestic workers from their commodity markets. Facebook also prohibits the use of the hashtag "خادمات للتنازل #" "#maidsfortransfer" which has been used as a tool.
There were no comments from the trading app for commodities from Saudi Arabia, Haraj.
Both Google and Apple told the BBC that this type of behavior had no place in their application market.
And they are working with application developers to improve the prevention of illegal activities on their platforms.
